categories.name: Historical Figures Who Changed the World

questions.clue: This 16th-century scientist formulated the laws of motion and universal gravitation.
In the 15th century, this explorer completed four voyages across the Atlantic Ocean, opening the way for the widespread European exploration of the Americas.
Known as the 'Father of India', this leader employed nonviolent resistance to lead the successful campaign for India's independence from British rule.
This 20th-century physicist developed the theory of relativity, fundamentally changing the understanding of space, time, and energy.
This 19th-century revolutionary thinker co-authored 'The Communist Manifesto', which became one of the world's most influential political documents.
This city is known for its deep-dish pizza and is the third most populous city in the United States.
Famous for its street food, this city is the capital of Thailand and home to the Grand Palace.
Renowned for its sushi and sashimi, this city is the capital of Japan and one of the world's most populous metropolises.
This city is a culinary capital in France, famous for its bouchons and Beaujolais wine.
Known for its rich culinary heritage, this city in Spain is famous for pintxos and holds more Michelin stars per capita than any other city.
This gas, essential for human respiration, makes up about 21% of Earth's atmosphere.
The pH scale measures how acidic or basic a substance is; pure water has this neutral pH value.
This simple sugar, a major source of energy for cells, is known by the chemical formula C6H12O6.
In terms of physics, this law states that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.
This term refers to the ability of a liquid to resist flowing, a property that makes honey thicker than water.
This author wrote '1984', a dystopian novel published in 1949.
Known for his tales of mystery, this author penned 'The Tell-Tale Heart'.
This author created the character Elizabeth Bennet in 'Pride and Prejudice'.
This Nobel laureate wrote 'One Hundred Years of Solitude', a landmark of magical realism.
Published in 1922, 'Ulysses' is a landmark modernist work by this Irish author.

categories.name: The Art of Cinema: Iconic Film Moments

questions.clue: In the 1994 film 'Forrest Gump,' this character famously says, 'Life is like a box of chocolates.'
In 'The Wizard of Oz,' Dorothy exclaims this line when she realizes she is no longer in Kansas.
This 1986 film features Tom Cruise in a memorable scene where he slides across the floor in his socks.
In 'Casablanca,' Rick Blaine tells Ilsa, 'Here's looking at you, kid,' in this classic 1942 film.
This 1976 film features Robert De Niro's character delivering the iconic line, 'You talkin' to me?' in front of a mirror.

final.clue: This city, whose name means 'Eastern Capital', became a capital city in 1868 during the Meiji Restoration and is now the most populous city in the world.
